[@tonybuidn](/tonybuidn) I edited the discussion. Thanks for pointing out the mistake!
x-2/3 is different from (x-2)/3 :)\nBut the formula that we want to get is (x + 2)/3, not x-2/3 or (x-2)/3
ans+=ceil((double)(x.second)/3);\nwe can do this to resolve what you said.

# Easy to understand, Beginner Friendly approach

<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
![image.png](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/ca029011-b3cf-4b23-8a3e-a20f7c675b56_1672819112.4886549.png)

In the picture above, we can see the minimum number of rounds for completing all tasks of same difficulty level (doing only 2 or 3 tasks in each round).
So, if there's a task which has a unique difficulty level (occured only once in the array `tasks[]`), we can't remove it.

If there are 5 tasks with same difficulty level, we can do 2 tasks in 1 round and rest of 3 in next round. Thus, min rounds required for 5 tasks with same difficulty level = 2.

I borrowed this explanation: 
If the frequency of a number is only 1, then it is not possible to solve this question, so we return -1.
If the frequency is directly divided by 3, then we return the frequency/3.
If the remainder of dividing the number by 3 is 1 or 2 then, again there can be two cases:
If remainder is 1, i.e, lets take 7 frequency, then o o o o o o o the groups are something like this "ooo" "ooo" "o", i.e, one o is left alone so the solution is to break the second last group into two parts of 2 and 1 so that it becomes like: "ooo" "oo" "oo", i.e, one is added to the division by 3.
If remainder is 2, i.e, lets take 8 frequency, then o o o o o o o o the groups are something like this "ooo" "ooo" "oo", i.e, two o are left so the solution is to just add 1,i.e, one group of two to the solution.
For calculating the frequency we have to use the hashmap.

you can formulate the total tasks as => n = 2*a + 3*b\nHence, whenever you add 2 to any count and than divide it by 3 it gets divided into the max possible values of a and b in the above equation.

I did the problem using HashMap which took almost 35ms whereas sorting array , counting occurrences  then solving took 10ms.\nisn\'t that O(n*log(n)) whereas HashMap is O(n)?\nwhy does performance differ this much?
[@Finesse](/Finesse) great explanation thank you

Because Big O only shows how the execution time increase when the input size increases. It doesn't consider the execution complexity that doesn't depend on the input size. HashMap is slow because it makes many calculations under the hood. While sorting is just swapping bytes in memory.

Let's say that one HashMap operation takes `10s` of time and one swapping operation takes `1s`. So the real time of the HashMap solution will be `n*10s` and the real time of the sorting solution will be `n*log(n)*1s`. If `n` is `10`, then the HashMap time will be `1000ms` and the sorting time will be `500ms`.

Conclusion: don't neglect the complexity of individual `O(1)` operations.

It\'s not that simple. I suggest reading up no only hash maps, but on the implementation you are using. For this problem there should be no collisions as they keys are integers. However, that is something to consider for other problems.\n\nAlso look up "stack vs heap performance".  Accessing data on the stack is always faster than the heap. There is also cache locality which comes into play.  These are all low level details which affect the runtime but not the time complexity of the algorithm. This is all important stuff to know.

Sort the array of tasks in ascending order.
Iterate through each task and count how many tasks have the same value.
If there is only one task with a particular value, return -1 since we cannot create any groups of 3 from these tasks.
Otherwise, add the number of full groups of 3 that can be created from the tasks with this value to the result.
If there are any remaining tasks that cannot be included in a group of 3, increment the result by 1 to indicate that another round is needed to process these tasks.
Return the total number of rounds needed to process all of the tasks.

Regarding time complexity for array vs hashmap. I think this debate will always come in such questions. As a thumb rule I avoid using a hashmap if the values are continuous since there can be an even better solution where we just initialize an array to all zeroes and use it just as a map, but due to memory constraints, it wont be wise to use it when range is >10^6. \n\nHaving said that, I don\'t think this question is about that, it is just a simple question for number theory and any way should be fine so I don\'t give much significance to \'Beats %\' as long as runtime is in sane limits.

[@sarpalmadhav](/sarpalmadhav) Are than any easier mediums than this? I was trying to see what the trick might be... I guess there kind of is one if you note that sorting O(nlogn) for 10^5 is still smaller than 10^9 so sorting solutions are actually faster than hashmap solutions despite the worse Time Complexity. Plus using a sorting method you can do it with O(1) space.
[@Sachin](/sachinbaral02) not really a medium, on the easy side of medium!

take map ...count the freq....check if map contain 1 or not

if yes `return -1;`

https://leetcode.com/problems/minimum-rounds-to-complete-all-tasks/submissions/871518370/ bro i did it but it was failing a testcase . you can have a look .

Sort the array of tasks in ascending order.
Iterate through each task and count how many tasks have the same value.
If there is only one task with a particular value, return -1 since we cannot create any groups of 3 from these tasks.
Otherwise, add the number of full groups of 3 that can be created from the tasks with this value to the result.
If there are any remaining tasks that cannot be included in a group of 3, increment the result by 1 to indicate that another round is needed to process these tasks.
Return the total number of rounds needed to process all of the tasks.

Well you only need to realise that 
1. If an element occurs only once, the condition is violated
2. tasks of any difficulty level takes `ceil(no_occurences/3)` rounds.
With this you have your solution.

same here, although mine was 75/79 case. I brute forced it by adding a loop counter. if the no. of loop exceeds 500, just print length of vector divided by count. The reason this worked is because my base logic was correct but slow and the later test cases had same count of occurrences for each task.

Me: Solved medium-level question in under 10 minutes\nOthers comment: This should be an easy question

The question looks complicated but all we need to understand is that any number greater than 1 can be split into rounds. If there is no task with difficulty level 1, then they can always be completed. We take as many 3\'s as we can and remaining are used by 2\'s.
the only condition for return -1 if count of a particular task ==1 otherwise if (count % 3 == 0) then result += 1 else result+=2;
We have to return -1 only if the frequency of any element is 1 otherwise, we can easily break them in parts of 3 and 2.
Why is this problem medium? It should be easy.
Isnt this a little on the easier side to be a medium question lol

There are 3 ways to solve this question.
1. Brute force method using visited array. We can count occurrence of each number and then calculate minimum rounds.
2. By sorting the given array, so that we don't have to iterate over array to get count of occurrences of a number.
3. Just use map to store the occurrence and then calculate by iterating over map.

Simply we just count tasks numbers in hash map then we iterate over it 
then we have 2 conditions 
- if the freqency of this task is 1 so we can't batch it in group of 2's or 3's  so **return -1**
- other wise mnRounds = freq/3 + (freq%3 != 0)

1. Brute force method using visited array. We can count occurrence of each number and then calculate minimum rounds.
2. By sorting the given array, so that we don't have to iterate over array to get count of occurrences of a number.
3. Just use map to store the occurrence and then calculate by iterating over map.

Simply we just count tasks numbers in hash map then we iterate over it 
then we have 2 conditions 
- if the freqency of this task is 1 so we can't batch it in group of 2's or 3's  so **return -1**
- other wise mnRounds = freq/3 + (freq%3 != 0)

The question looks complicated but all we need to understand is that any number greater than 1 can be split into rounds. If there is no task with difficulty level 1, then they can always be completed. We take as many 3\'s as we can and remaining are used by 2\'s.
the only condition for return -1 if count of a particular task ==1 otherwise if (count % 3 == 0) then result += 1 else result+=2;
We have to return -1 only if the frequency of any element is 1 otherwise, we can easily break them in parts of 3 and 2.

[@sarpalmadhav](/sarpalmadhav)  Thank you so much!! Because of your suggestion i removed each occurence of count function from my code and it worked!! Keep spreading the knowledge and helping ppl in need :)
[@sarpalmadhav](/sarpalmadhav) thank you brother. I was unaware about the fact that count function is very expensive. thats why it is showing TLE\n

[@Uday](/udaybhardwaj01) That\'s not how you should count, the count function is very expensive, in each loop it will check full array. You are making this a n*n solution this way and it will give TLE for 10^5 nums. Just sort it and start from i = 0 and then move forward until the element is same, this is how you will get count for cur element.. then continue from next index, Don\'t do this pop_back logic, even pop_back is expensive when all we have to do is read the sorted array.

Lang: C++11

`#define D (int)1e9`
`int minimumRounds(vector<int>& tasks) {`
`    int cnt[D+1], ans=0;`
`    for (int t:tasks) ++cnt[t];`
`        for (int i=1; i<=D; ++i) {`
`          `  `if (!cnt[i]) continue;`
`           `  `if (cnt[i]==1) return -1;`
`           `  `ans += (cnt[i]+2)/3;`
`    }`
`    return ans;`
`}`

Thanks in advance.
[@sarpalmadhav](/sarpalmadhav) Thanks for your quick answer! My first optimization would be to find the mininum and maximum difficulties, in order to limit the lower and upper bound for the loop.

[@kyriakoskourk](/kyriakoskourk), This has obvious loopholes, that #define D 1e9 is a nuclear bomb. You cant do 1e9 operations in 2 sec time limit. So that it self is big No. Also, Stack overlflow might be because you cant just right an int array of 1e9. At 4 bytes per int, you are asking for 4 GB of memory!!. As a thumb rule never declare static int array of more than 1e6 size. Regarding question, you will need to optimize approach. Read hashmaps or maybe read about how to sort and count frequencies in an array.

here we need to take frequencies of tasks[i] to count the level of difficulty

then traverse the frequency loop and check if(freq[i]<2) return -1 
else if(freq[i]>3) check remainder of freq[i]%3  if it is 0 direct add quotient to answer else add quotient+1 to answer .

finally return answerl
finally good old hashmap, this should be an easy problem.
ceil(freq/3)

we should make a map and store all the frequency of the numbers.
then we traverse through the map ans check for every element.
if any element has frequency<2 then we should return at that very point . ans will be -1.
in a general sense an element can be picked in a multiple number of 2 and 3. lets say we take x1 turns where we pick up 2 pieces of that element and x2 turns where we take 3 pieces of that element in a go.


we represent a equation 2*x1+3*x2=y 
where y is the element's frequency.  if a integer pair exists (x1,x2) that satisfies the equation, we take it. if there are a lot of that solution pair, we take the pair having the smallest sum (x1+x2).

finally good old hashmap, this should be an easy problem.
ceil(freq/3)

we should make a map and store all the frequency of the numbers.
then we traverse through the map ans check for every element.
if any element has frequency<2 then we should return at that very point . ans will be -1.
in a general sense an element can be picked in a multiple number of 2 and 3. lets say we take x1 turns where we pick up 2 pieces of that element and x2 turns where we take 3 pieces of that element in a go.


we represent a equation 2*x1+3*x2=y 
where y is the element's frequency.  if a integer pair exists (x1,x2) that satisfies the equation, we take it. if there are a lot of that solution pair, we take the pair having the smallest sum (x1+x2).

Its more of a Math topic problem may be.

From observation, we can see that there's only 3 possible outcomes.
1. If the frequency is 1, the task cannot be performed so we return -1.
2. If the frequency is 3, the task can be performed and we return frequency/3.
3. Now if the frequency is not completely divisible by 3, then we can return frequency/3 +1.

`   // minwork return   [-1,1,1,2,2,2,3,3,3]`

You don\'t have to it will develope automatically just practice as many questions as possible \nHere is my solution which is similar to climbing stairs problem or coin change problem:\nhttps://leetcode.com/problems/minimum-rounds-to-complete-all-tasks/solutions/2995390/intuitive-memoization-using-coin-change-explained/

[@Santanu Sen](/santanusen) That\'s one way of giving the full answer in as little words as possible! This is a perfect spoiler for those who have not thought about it, but I like the brevity!!
really help , thanks!!
Well we can solve this problem using dp ( top down approach)
My code is not satisfying the first test case here but is running perfectly on other compilers with the same testcases. What do I do?
a basic greedy question \uD83D\uDE0B\uD83D\uDE0B
Far better than the last one

My approach was to get an occurrence count table for how many times each task number occurred. Then I iterated through the table, and found whether each number\'s count can be split by 2s and 3s. The only occasion it would return -1 would be the number only occurred 1 time. The hard part then was to think about how to come up with the condition that checks the minimum step count to cut up the tasks count in 2s and 3s. Since you divide any number larger than 3, if it doesn\'t have remainder, great, add that divided number to the result sum. But if it doesn\'t, the remainder would be either 2 or 1. Since we omitted the 1 from failure condition, I was thinking we could simple get a 3 from counted, and cut the 4 to 2 2s. Which eventually becomes if there is a remainder, add one to the divide by 3 number, and eventually to the res. After iterating through the table, you will either return -1 midway when found 1, or return the correct result.

Question is similar to climbing stairs where we can go climb 2 or 3 steps from current stair and have to find minimum:\nHere is my memoized solution:\nhttps://leetcode.com/problems/minimum-rounds-to-complete-all-tasks/solutions/2995390/intuitive-memoization-using-coin-change-explained/
11 can be split up into 3+3+3+2 in total 4 tasks...
Hashtable is not needed if we sort the input array.
with hashtable it could be resolved in `O(n)`, and sorting is `O(nlogn)`.
Simple recursion problem similar to factorial use dp array not to get TLE

yes but you dont have to create freq to each element , just sort that array and using topdown approach , you can check it here\n\nhttps://leetcode.com/problems/minimum-rounds-to-complete-all-tasks/solutions/2995897/go-top-down-knapsack-dp/?orderBy=most_relevant

title: Largest 3-Same-Digit Number in String
question_content:
You are given a string num representing a large integer. An integer is good if it meets the following conditions:

  • It is a substring of num with length 3.
  • It consists of only one unique digit.

Return the maximum good integer as a string or an empty string "" if no such integer exists.

Note:

  • A substring is a contiguous sequence of characters within a string.
  • There may be leading zeroes in num or a good integer.

 

Example 1:

Input: num = "6777133339"
Output: "777"
Explanation: There are two distinct good integers: "777" and "333".
"777" is the largest, so we return "777".

Example 2:

Input: num = "2300019"
Output: "000"
Explanation: "000" is the only good integer.

Example 3:

Input: num = "42352338"
Output: ""
Explanation: No substring of length 3 consists of only one unique digit. Therefore, there are no good integers.

 

Constraints:

  • 3 <= num.length <= 1000
  • num only consists of digits.

```
class Solution:
    def largestGoodInteger(self, num: str) -> str:
        ss = 0
        res=''
        for i in set(num):
            if i*3 in num:
                if ss <= int(i):
                    ss = int(i)
                    res=i*3
        return res
```

```
class Solution:
    def largestGoodInteger(self, num: str) -> str:
        good_number = ""
        for i in range(1, len(num) - 1):
            if num[i - 1] == num[i] and num[i] == num[i + 1]:
                good_number = max(num[i - 1:i + 2], good_number)

        return good_number
```

# Intuition
- Create a list of repeated nums and return the max of that list.
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

# Complexity
- Time complexity: O(n)
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
 
# Code
```
class Solution:
    def largestGoodInteger(self, num: str) -> str:
        if not num:
            return ''
        num=str(num)
        ans=[]
        for i in range(0,len((num))-2):
            if num[i]==num[i+1]==num[i+2]:
                ans.append((num)[i])
        
        if ans:
            return max(ans)*3
        else:return ''

```

title: Count Integers in Intervals
question_content:
Given an empty set of intervals, implement a data structure that can:

  • Add an interval to the set of intervals.
  • Count the number of integers that are present in at least one interval.

Implement the CountIntervals class:

  • CountIntervals() Initializes the object with an empty set of intervals.
  • void add(int left, int right) Adds the interval [left, right] to the set of intervals.
  • int count() Returns the number of integers that are present in at least one interval.

Note that an interval [left, right] denotes all the integers x where left <= x <= right.

 

Example 1:

Input
["CountIntervals", "add", "add", "count", "add", "count"]
[[], [2, 3], [7, 10], [], [5, 8], []]
Output
[null, null, null, 6, null, 8]

Explanation
CountIntervals countIntervals = new CountIntervals(); // initialize the object with an empty set of intervals. 
countIntervals.add(2, 3);  // add [2, 3] to the set of intervals.
countIntervals.add(7, 10); // add [7, 10] to the set of intervals.
countIntervals.count();    // return 6
                           // the integers 2 and 3 are present in the interval [2, 3].
                           // the integers 7, 8, 9, and 10 are present in the interval [7, 10].
countIntervals.add(5, 8);  // add [5, 8] to the set of intervals.
countIntervals.count();    // return 8
                           // the integers 2 and 3 are present in the interval [2, 3].
                           // the integers 5 and 6 are present in the interval [5, 8].
                           // the integers 7 and 8 are present in the intervals [5, 8] and [7, 10].
                           // the integers 9 and 10 are present in the interval [7, 10].

 

Constraints:

  • 1 <= left <= right <= 109
  • At most 105 calls in total will be made to add and count.
  • At least one call will be made to count.

solutions.content:
### Idea
1. Initialize list `interv` with  `[(-inf, -inf), (inf, inf)]` to store the merged intervals and integer `cov = 0`, to be updated after addition of each interval
2. Whenever an interval must be added, the following must be done
- Using binary search, find the range of affected intervals in `interv`, denoted by `li` for left most, `ri` for right most + 1
- the range of the new merged interval (`lval`, `rval`)
- replace the range of [li, ri - 1], inclusive with the new merged interval `(lval, rval)`
3. Update the coverege by
- Finding and subtracting the coverage of deleted intervals `to_delete`
- Adding the coverage of new interval `rval - lval + 1`

### Code
#### Built-in List
```
class CountIntervals:

    def __init__(self):
	# initialize the merged intervals list as below to handle edge cases
        self.interv = [(-inf, -inf), (inf, inf)]
        self.cov = 0   

    def add(self, left: int, right: int) -> None:
        
        interv = self.interv
        
		# find the left most position for inserting of the new potentially merged interval
		# we use `left - 1` because the interval coverage is inclusive
        li = bisect.bisect_left(interv, left - 1, key=itemgetter(1))
        lval = min(interv[li][0], left)
		
		# find the right most position for inserting the new potentially merged interval
		# we use `right + 1` because the interval coverage is inclusive
        ri = bisect.bisect_right(interv, right + 1, key=itemgetter(0))
        rval = max(interv[ri - 1][1], right)

		# find the coverage of the intervals that will be replaced by the new interval
        to_delete = 0
        for _ in range(li, ri):
            to_delete += interv[_][1] - interv[_][0] + 1
            
		# udpate the coverage
        self.cov += rval - lval + 1 - to_delete
        interv[li: ri] = [(lval, rval)]

    def count(self) -> int:
        return self.cov
```

#### SortedList
```
from sortedcontainers import SortedList

class CountIntervals:

    def __init__(self):
        self.cov = 0 
        self.interv = SortedList([(-inf, -inf), (inf, inf)])

    def add(self, left: int, right: int) -> None:
        li = self.interv.bisect_left((left - 1, -inf))
        if self.interv[li - 1][1] >= left - 1:
            li -= 1
        lval = min(self.interv[li][0], left)
        ri = self.interv.bisect_right((right + 1, inf))
        rval = max(self.interv[ri - 1][1], right)
        
        
        to_delete = 0
        for _ in range(li, ri):
            to_delete += self.interv[_][1] - self.interv[_][0] + 1
        self.cov += rval - lval + 1 - to_delete
        del self.interv[li: ri]
        self.interv.add((lval, rval))

    def count(self) -> int:
        return self.cov
```

### Feedback
I appreciate your feedback and support! :)

solutions.content:
Please pull this [commit](https://github.com/gaosanyong/leetcode/commit/5edf72d3865cd9791f0a89b968c0c1aeeaa381c3) for solutions of weekly 293. 

```
from sortedcontainers import SortedList

class CountIntervals:

    def __init__(self):
        self.cnt = 0 
        self.intervals = SortedList()

    def add(self, left: int, right: int) -> None:
        k = self.intervals.bisect_left((left, right))
        while k < len(self.intervals) and self.intervals[k][0] <= right: 
            l, r = self.intervals.pop(k)
            self.cnt -= r - l + 1
            right = max(right, r)
        if k and left <= self.intervals[k-1][1]: 
            l, r = self.intervals.pop(k-1)
            self.cnt -= r - l + 1
            left = l
            right = max(right, r)
        self.cnt += right - left + 1
        self.intervals.add((left, right))

    def count(self) -> int:
        return self.cnt
```

solutions.content:
**Approach**
1. If there is no intervals yet, just add it and keep track of the count. Otherwise:
2. Search through intervals for where left of the new interval is less than the end of any interval.
3. Search through intervals for where right of the new interval is greater than the start of any interval.
4. If our found left index is inside an interval, take the minimum of it and the interval.
5. If our found right index is inside of an interval, take hte maximum of it and the interval.
6. Otherwise [left, right] will be inserted into the list. 
7. Keep track of counts as we go, we're going to add to counts the amount of the new interval
8. We're going to remove from counts all intervals between our left index and right index. If we're just inserting, the space between left index and right index will be 0. So we'll only be adding.

**Other Considerations**
In the competition two things caused my time limit exceeded:
1. Not keeping track of counts and walking it instead. One of the test cases is, add add add... for 50+ iterations followed by count count count... for 100+ iterations. So if you have to walk count each time, you'll TLE.
2. Even with that, updating the interval list afterwards with array slicing. This is confusing for me.

Had to look at yag313's solution to see array slice + assignment which is much much faster. I think python does extra memory allocation and will add two arrays together followed by another addition of the third array in my naive attempt.

***Would love a detailed explanation from anyone on what the time complexity between the two lines are please.***

```
import bisect
from operator import itemgetter

class CountIntervals:

    def __init__(self):
        self.intervals = []
        self.cur_count = 0

    def add(self, left: int, right: int) -> None:
        if not self.intervals:
            self.intervals.append([left, right])
            self.cur_count = right - left + 1
            return

        l = bisect.bisect_left(self.intervals, left, key=itemgetter(1))
        r = bisect.bisect_right(self.intervals, right, key=itemgetter(0))
        
        if l < len(self.intervals):
            left = min(left, self.intervals[l][0])
            
        if r > 0:
            right = max(right, self.intervals[r-1][1])
        
        to_add = right - left + 1
        
        to_remove = 0
        for i in range(l, r):
            to_remove += self.intervals[i][1] - self.intervals[i][0] + 1
            
        self.cur_count += to_add - to_remove
        
        # TOO SLOW!!
        # 15 seconds!!
        # self.intervals = self.intervals[:l] + [[left, right]] + self.intervals[r:]
        
        # 1.3 - 1.6 seconds
        self.intervals[l:r] = [[left, right]]

    def count(self) -> int:
        return self.cur_count


# Your CountIntervals object will be instantiated and called as such:
# obj = CountIntervals()
# obj.add(left,right)
# param_2 = obj.count()
```

python3-sorted-list-merge-intervals-in-stream-fb-follow-up-for-56
solutions.content:
Directly modified from my another post of solution: https://leetcode.com/problems/merge-intervals/discuss/1889983/python-binary-search-solution-for-fb-follow-up-merge-in-stream

#### Original idea
This is the idea when I tried to come up with the solution for the follow-up question of 56 with out BST:

The basic idea of the solution is, when we merge intervals we are placing the points on a line segment. Let's denote start points as 0 and endpoints as 1 for separating different points, then we could get a representation. For instance, merged intervals: [1, 4], [7, 9], we could denote as
[1,0], [4, 1], [7, 0], [9, 1]

Then every time we have a new start and end, we could insert [st, 0], [ed, 1] to this list.

There are 2 key observations for this representations:

1. we should not get 2 continous start or 2 continous end.
For instance, if after insert we get sth. like [1,0], [2, 0], [3, 1], [4,1], we know a merge should happens.

2. If it is an insertion that will not trigger any merges, we could know that the place we insert start and end should differ only by 1.
For instance, we already have [1,0], [4,1] denotes the merged interval [1, 4] and we want to insert [5, 6] , we will get the index to insert is 2 and 3 which differs by 1

Based on 1 and 2, let's denote the place to insert [st, 0] is idx1 and [ed, 1] is idx2, then:

1. if idx2 - idx1 != 1, we know the elements between should be removed
2. If we encounter invalid situation #1, we set idx1 = idx1 - 1 or idx2 = idx2 + 1 for further checks


#### Update specified for this problem
To further modify for this question, we need to maintain a count variable and update it when new intervals come.

We added the number of [st, ed] for all new intervals to be added, and then remove the duplicates when we pop out the intervals that should cause duplicate additions.

```Python
from sortedcontainers import SortedList
class CountIntervals:

    def __init__(self):
        self.sorted_list = SortedList()
        self.num = 0

    def add(self, st: int, ed: int) -> None:
        self.sorted_list.add([st, 0])
        self.sorted_list.add([ed, 1])
        
        self.num += ed - st + 1
        # print(self.sorted_list)
        
        idx1 = self.sorted_list.index([st, 0])
        idx2 = self.sorted_list.index([ed, 1])
        
     
        if idx1 - 1 >= 0 and self.sorted_list[idx1 - 1][1] == 0:
            idx1 -= 1
        if idx2 + 1 < len(self.sorted_list) and self.sorted_list[idx2 + 1][1] == 1:
            idx2 += 1
        
        if idx2 - idx1 != 1:
            j = idx1 + 1
            for _ in range(idx1 + 1, idx2):
                if self.sorted_list[j][1] == 0: # encounter a start point need to be remove
                    self.num -= (self.sorted_list[j + 1][0] - self.sorted_list[j][0] + 1) # so we need to decrease the duplicated addition to the total number
                self.sorted_list.pop(j)

    def count(self) -> int: # O(1)
        return self.num
```

solutions.content:
My basic idea is using a dictionary to represent the left and right boundary of intervals. 
1. Insert keys into map.
	if we add intervals [2, 3], [7, 10], [5, 8], the dict `boundary_cnt` will be  {2: 1, 4: -1, 5: 1, 7: 1, 9: -1,11: -1} (the value is sorted)
2. Go through the intervals and count.
	Use `cur_sum` to decide if we reach the left boundary or right boundary of an interval. Initailize the left boundary with -1. `cur_sum += boundary_cnt[v]` , if `cur_sum > 0`, v must be in the interval. if `cur_sum == 0`, v is the right boundary of the interval. 
For example, 
v = 2, cur_sum = 1, since `left` = -1, v = 2 is the left boundary of interval
v = 4, cur_sum = 0, v = 4 is right most one. The length of this interval is 2. Then we re-initialize the `left`
v = 5, cur_sum = 1, find a new `left`
v = 7, cur_sum = 2, it's not the left nor right, we can delete the key 
v = 9, cur_sum = 1, same as above
v = 11, cur_sum = 0, finally find the `right`.  The length of this interval is 6, total count is 8. In the meanwhile, since we delete some keys between (5, 11), to make sure we can still find the paired left and right next time, update the value of `boundary_cnt[11]`


```
class CountIntervals:

    def __init__(self):
        self.boundary_cnt = defaultdict(int)
        self.cur_res = -1
        
    def add(self, left: int, right: int) -> None:
        self.boundary_cnt[left] += 1
        self.boundary_cnt[right + 1] -= 1
        self.cur_res = -1
        
    def count(self) -> int:
        if not self.boundary_cnt:
            return 0
        if self.cur_res != -1:
            return self.cur_res
        
        res = 0
        values = sorted(self.boundary_cnt.keys())
        left = -1
        cur_sum = 0

        for v in values:
            if v not in self.boundary_cnt:
                continue
            
            cur_sum += self.boundary_cnt[v]
            if left == -1:
                if cur_sum > 0:
                    left = v
                continue
                
            if cur_sum > 0:
                del self.boundary_cnt[v]
            else:
                right = v
                res += right - left 
                self.boundary_cnt[v] = - self.boundary_cnt[left]
                left = -1

        self.cur_res = res
        return res
```

solutions.content:
**Idea**: stored a list of interval points, where the even indices are the start points (included) of the intervals and odd indices are the end points (excluded) of the intervals. For example, 
the intervals [[2, 3], [7, 10]] is stored as [2, 4, 7, 11]

When adding a new interval, I use binary search to find the insertion points (bisect_left for the start points and bisect_right to the end points). I add the new intervals and delete the intervals in between.

However, I need to handle the case when the indicies of the insertion points are odd, which means the points are within existing intervals. For example, adding [5, 9) to [2, 4, 7, 11], the insertion point of 5 is 2, so it is fine, while the insertion point of 9 is 3, so I need to move it to the right (11). 
Another example, adding [3, 5) to [2, 4, 7, 11], the insertion points are 1 and 2, so I moved the insertion points of 3 to the left (2).

When adding and deleting the intervals, I also store the value of the total interval count.

**Python**

```
class CountIntervals:

    def __init__(self):
        self.intervals = []
        self.c = 0

    def add(self, left: int, right: int) -> None:
        right += 1
        i = bisect_left(self.intervals, left)
        j = bisect_right(self.intervals, right)

        if i % 2 == 1:
            left = self.intervals[i-1]
            i -= 1
            
        if j % 2 == 1:
            right = self.intervals[j]
            j += 1
            
        for k in range(i, j, 2):
             self.c -= self.intervals[k+1] - self.intervals[k]        
        
        self.c += right - left
        self.intervals[i:j] = [left, right]
        
    def count(self) -> int:
        return self.c
```

solutions.content:
I understand that in python, SortedDict is alter of TreeMap.
But why there isn't floorEntity or cellingEntity?  That makes me feel stupid.
Should I use Java next time when it comes? or I just use floorEntity anyway in python in real interview?

```
from sortedcontainers import SortedDict
class CountIntervals:

    def __init__(self):
        self.SD = SortedDict()
        self.total = 0
		
	# from the right most of insert, merge all saved lefts that less than it, until no next left or no overlapping next left.
	# (reason we choose R to L is, R is natually 'hiden' in treemap and not able to bisect.
	# E.g   we insert with right 8, so for 5 - 9, floor of 8 (5) is what we just need for merging from right to left.
    def add(self, left: int, right: int) -> None:
		# Added 1 here, as I hope 'right' means "the just next one of the current interval", it's easier with '-'.
        right += 1 
        while True:
            i = self.SD.bisect_right(right) -1 # that bisect_right is inferior to floorEntity in TreeMap
            if i < 0:
                break
            savedLeft, savedRight = self.SD.peekitem(i)
            if savedRight < left:
                break
            
            self.total -= (savedRight -savedLeft)
            self.SD.popitem(i)
            left = min(left, savedLeft)
            right = max(right, savedRight)
            
        self.total += (right - left)
        self.SD[left] = right

    def count(self) -> int:
        return self.total
		```

solutions.content:
1. We save non-overlapping intervals by two arrays, `self.L` and `self.R`. `[self.L[i], self.R[i]]` is the `i`th interval.
2. When a new interval `I = [left, right]` is added, use binary search to find:
	- `idx_l`: index of the first interval whose right endpoint >= `left`.
	- `idx_r`: index of the first interval whose left endpoint > `right` .
Here are some examples:
![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/1f6cfb34-b2b7-4b98-9963-249588b92a40_1680449623.203056.png)
	- case 1: `idx_l = 2, idx_r = 4`.
	- case 2: `idx_l = 1, idx_r = 4`.
	- case 3: `idx_l = 2, idx_r = 3`.
3. From `idx_r-1` to `idx_l`, pop the interval one by one. Each time an interval is popped out, merge it with `I`.
4. After all overlapping intervals are popped out, insert the merged `I`.
```
from bisect import bisect_left, bisect_right

class CountIntervals:
    def __init__(self):
        self.L = []
        self.R = []
        self.total = 0

    def add(self, left: int, right: int) -> None:
        if not self.L:
            self.L.append(left)
            self.R.append(right)
            self.total += right-left+1
        else:
            idx_l, idx_r = bisect_left(self.R, left), bisect_right(self.L, right)
            lm, rm = left, right
            while idx_l < idx_r:
                l1 = self.L.pop(idx_r-1)
                r1 = self.R.pop(idx_r-1)
                self.total -= r1-l1+1
                lm = min(lm, l1)
                rm = max(rm, r1)
                idx_r -= 1
            self.L.insert(idx_l, lm)
            self.R.insert(idx_l, rm)
            self.total += rm-lm+1
        
    def count(self) -> int:
        return self.total
```

from bisect import bisect_left, bisect_right

class CountIntervals:
    def __init__(self):
        self.L = []
        self.R = []
        self.total = 0

    def add(self, left: int, right: int) -> None:
        if not self.L:
            self.L.append(left)
            self.R.append(right)
            self.total += right-left+1
        else:
            idx_l, idx_r = bisect_left(self.R, left), bisect_right(self.L, right)
            lm, rm = left, right
            while idx_l < idx_r:
                l1 = self.L.pop(idx_r-1)
                r1 = self.R.pop(idx_r-1)
                self.total -= r1-l1+1
                lm = min(lm, l1)
                rm = max(rm, r1)
                idx_r -= 1
            self.L.insert(idx_l, lm)
            self.R.insert(idx_l, rm)
            self.total += rm-lm+1
        
    def count(self) -> int:
        return self.total

solutions.content:
**SortedDict**

```python
from sortedcontainers import SortedDict

class CountIntervals(object):

    def __init__(self):
		# { right -> left } sorted by key (right end of the interval)
        self.d = SortedDict()
        # sum of all merged intervals == number of integers that are present in at least one interval.
        self.cnt = 0 

    def add(self, left, right):
        """
        :type left: int
        :type right: int
        :rtype: None
        """
        # Find the first interval whose key >= left, i.e. whose right end >= left
        i = self.d.bisect_left(left)
        # iterate all the intervals covered or partially covered by [left, right] 
        while i < len(self.d) and self.d.values()[i] <= right:
            r, l = self.d.items()[i]
            # Merge interval into a new larger interal:
            left = min(left, l)
            right = max(right, r)
            # Subtracting the sum of merged smaller interval
            self.cnt -= r - l + 1
            # deleted the merged smaller interval from the SortedDict
            self.d.popitem(i)
        
        # Adding by the sum of merged larger interval
        self.cnt += right - left + 1
        # Add the new merged interval 
        self.d[right] = left

    def count(self):
        """
        :rtype: int
        """
        return self.cnt
      

# Your CountIntervals object will be instantiated and called as such:
# obj = CountIntervals()
# obj.add(left,right)
# param_2 = obj.count()

```

`Time = log(N)`: each interval will be update (add/delete) once at most , so the amortized time complexity of `add` is O(logN), N is the number of time of `add` was called.
`Space = O(N)`: SortedDict

**SortedList**
Same idea, just replace {right -> left} with the tuple (right, left)

```python
from sortedcontainers import SortedList

class CountIntervals:

    def __init__(self):
        self.cnt = 0 
        self.intervals = SortedList()

    def add(self, left, right):
        k = self.intervals.bisect_left((left - 1, right))
        while k < len(self.intervals) and self.intervals[k][1] <= right: 
            r, l = self.intervals.pop(k)
            self.cnt -= r - l + 1
            right = max(right, r)
            left = min(left, l)
            
        self.cnt += right - left + 1
        self.intervals.add((right, left))

    def count(self):
        return self.cnt

```

```python
class CountIntervals:
```

```
        while pos<len(self.arr):

            left = min(left, self.arr[pos][0])

        self.arr.insert(pos, (left, right))  
        self.cnt+=right-left+1
```

racket-skip-list-solution
solutions.content:
Find overlapping intervals, remove and merge them with new `left` and `right`.
Finally, insert new `left` and `right`.

There are two ordered dict implementation in Racket: splay-tree and skip-list.
splay-tree can't pass on Leetcode while skip-list can.

```scheme
(require data/skip-list)

(define count-intervals%
  (class object%
    (super-new)

    (init-field [m (make-skip-list)]
                [cnt 0])

    (define (len lower upper)
      (- upper lower -1))

    (define/public (add left right)
      (let loop ([pos (dict-iterate-least/>=? m left)])
        (when pos
          (let ([lower (dict-iterate-value m pos)]
                [upper (dict-iterate-key m pos)])
            (when (<= lower right)
              (set! left (min left lower))
              (set! right (max right upper))
              (set! cnt (- cnt (len lower upper))) 

              (dict-remove! m upper)
              (loop (dict-iterate-next m pos))))))

      (set! cnt (+ cnt (len left right)))
      (dict-set! m right left))

    (define/public (count)
      cnt)))
```

```scheme
                [upper (dict-iterate-key m pos)])

              (set! right (max right upper))
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
We solve the problem by merging the intervals and keeping the count updated at the same time.

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
When a new interval comes we check whether it can be merged with any other interval or not. If it merges with one interval or many, we do that by deleting the interval first while keeping the left and right boundary updated.

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
$$O(nˆ2)$$
In details the time complexity is O(n*(logN + N) + N)
- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
$$O(n)$$

# Code
```
class CountIntervals:
    def __init__(self):
        self.intervals = []
        self.cnt = 0

    def add(self, left: int, right: int) -> None:
        l,r = left,right

        while True:
            idx = bisect.bisect_left(self.intervals, (r, ))
            if not len(self.intervals):
                break
            if (idx == 0 and self.intervals[idx][0] > right) or self.intervals[idx-1][1] < l:
                break
            
            prev_l, prev_r = self.intervals[idx-1]
            self.cnt -= (prev_r - prev_l + 1)
            del self.intervals[idx - 1]

            l = min(prev_l, l)
            r = max(prev_r, r)
        
        self.intervals.insert(idx, (l,r))
        self.cnt += (r - l + 1)

    def count(self) -> int:
        return self.cnt
        


# Your CountIntervals object will be instantiated and called as such:
# obj = CountIntervals()
```

```
class CountIntervals:
    def __init__(self):
        self.intervals = []
        self.cnt = 0

    def add(self, left: int, right: int) -> None:
        l,r = left,right

        while True:
            idx = bisect.bisect_left(self.intervals, (r, ))
            if not len(self.intervals):
                break
            if (idx == 0 and self.intervals[idx][0] > right) or self.intervals[idx-1][1] < l:
                break
            
            prev_l, prev_r = self.intervals[idx-1]
            self.cnt -= (prev_r - prev_l + 1)
            del self.intervals[idx - 1]

            l = min(prev_l, l)
            r = max(prev_r, r)
        
        self.intervals.insert(idx, (l,r))
        self.cnt += (r - l + 1)

    def count(self) -> int:
        return self.cnt
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
Keep track of the count and merge intervals as you add them.

# Approach
0. Initialize intervals to include endpoints for comparison and count to 0

1. Find all intervals that will merge with the new interval, using binary search.  (Because @intervals was initialized with endpoints outside the range, both bsearches will always return a valid index.)
2. Find the ends of the merged interval.  Note that you use r-1 for the right side, because bsearch finds the first interval that will *not* merge.
3. Increment count by the the number of integers in the merged interval.
4. Decrement count by the number of integers in each interval that's being removed.
5. Replace the old intervals that merge with the new interval.

6. Return @count for count.

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
$$O(n)$$ for add, $$O(1)$$ for initialize and count

- Space complexity:
$$O(n)$$

# Code
```
class CountIntervals
    def initialize()
        @intervals = [[0,0],[Float::INFINITY,Float::INFINITY]]
        @count = 0
    end

    def add(left, right)

        len = @intervals.length
        l = (0...len).bsearch { |i| @intervals[i][1] >= left } # end is bigger than left -- could merge
        r = (0...len).bsearch { |i| @intervals[i][0] > right } # start is bigger than right -- first interval that can't merge

        int_left = [left,@intervals[l][0]].min
        int_right = [right,@intervals[r-1][1]].max

        @count += int_right - int_left + 1

        (l...r).each do |i|
            int = @intervals[i]
            remove = int[1] - int[0] + 1
            @count -= remove
        end

        @intervals[l...r] = [[int_left,int_right]]
    end

    def count()
        @count
    end

end
```

# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
This uses a list of numbers instead of list of lists which all other solutions are using. 

If the index of the number to be added is even, it means there is no overlap and we can insert/replace it as a subinterval.

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
Similar to [Range Module](https://leetcode.com/problems/range-module/) problem

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
    O(N) to add
    O(1) to search

- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->


# Code
```
class CountIntervals:
    def __init__(self):
        self.interval = []
        self.cnt = 0

    # TC - add - O(N)
    def add(self, left: int, right: int) -> None:
        left_idx = bisect.bisect_left(self.interval, left)
        right_idx = bisect.bisect_right(self.interval, right)

        subinterval = []
        if left_idx % 2 == 0:
            subinterval.append(left)
        if right_idx % 2 == 0:
            subinterval.append(right)
        
        # Replace/add the interval
        self.interval[left_idx:right_idx] = subinterval
        
        if len(subinterval) == 2 and len(self.interval[left_idx:right_idx]) == 0:
            self.cnt += abs(subinterval[1]-subinterval[0]+1)
        else:
            # Recalculating - Optimization possible here
            self.cnt = 0
            for i in range(0,len(self.interval),2):
                self.cnt += abs(self.interval[i+1] - self.interval[i] + 1) 
        
    def count(self) -> int:
        return self.cnt

# Your CountIntervals object will be instantiated and called as such:
# obj = CountIntervals()
# obj.add(left,right)
# param_2 = obj.count()

```

solutions.content:
```python
class CountIntervals:

    def __init__(self):
        self.intervals = []
        self.total = 0

    def add(self, left: int, right: int) -> None:
        # insert
        index = bisect.bisect(self.intervals, [left, right])
        self.intervals.insert(index, [left, right])
        self.total += right - left + 1

        # merge
        i, j = max(0, index - 1), len(self.intervals) - 1
        while i < j:
            if self.intervals[i][1] + 1 < self.intervals[i+1][0]:
                i += 1
                continue

            # calculate difference
            a = self.intervals[i+0][1] - self.intervals[i+0][0] + 1
            b = self.intervals[i+1][1] - self.intervals[i+1][0] + 1
            c = a + b

            self.intervals[i][1] = max(self.intervals[i][1], self.intervals[i+1][1])
            self.total -= c - (self.intervals[i][1] - self.intervals[i][0] + 1)

            # remove next
            self.intervals.pop(i + 1)
            j -= 1

    def count(self) -> int:
        return self.total
```

<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
- Use set in order to keep intervals in sorted order.
- Find the overlapping intervals and erase them.
- Add the new intervals.
- Keep the count of the number of elements.

# Complexity
- Time complexity: O(N + logN)
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity: O(N)
Where, N = Number of intervals.

# Code
```
class CountIntervals {
    set<pair<int, int>> st;
    int cnt = 0;
public:
    CountIntervals() {
        cnt = 0;
    }
    
    void add(int left, int right) {
        auto it = st.upper_bound({left, INT_MIN});
        if(it != st.begin() && (--it)->second < left) {
            ++it;
        }
        
        while(it != st.end() && it->first <= right) {
            left = min(left, it->first);
            right = max(right, it->second);
            
            cnt -= (it->second - it->first + 1);
            it = st.erase(it);
        }
        
        st.insert({ left, right });
        cnt += (right - left + 1);
    }
    
    int count() {
        return cnt;
    }
};

/**
 * Your CountIntervals object will be instantiated and called as such:
 * CountIntervals* obj = new CountIntervals();
 * obj->add(left,right);
 * int param_2 = obj->count();
 */
```

# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Node:
    def __init__(self):
        self.val = self.left = self.right = None

    def add(self, node, x, y, s, e):
        if e <= x or y <= s or node and node.val == y-x: return node

        if not node: node = Node()

        if s <= x and y <= e:
            node.val = y-x
            return node

        mid = (x+y)//2

        node.left = self.add(node.left, x, mid, s, e)
        node.right = self.add(node.right, mid, y, s, e)

        node.val = 0

        if node.left: node.val += node.left.val
        if node.right: node.val += node.right.val 

        return node

class CountIntervals:
    def __init__(self):
        self.root = Node()

    def add(self, left, right):
        self.root.add(self.root,1,10**9+1,left,right+1)

    def count(self):
        return self.root.val or 0
        
```

solutions.content:
# Complexity
- add(): Amortized O(log(n)). Multiple existing key-value pairs may be deleted in an add() operation, but the number of deleted keys is never more than the number of previous add() calls.
- count(): O(1).
- Space complexity: O(n).

Where n is number of calls of add() and count().
# Code
```elixir
defmodule CountIntervals do
  use GenServer

  @spec init_() :: any
  def init_() do
    GenServer.start_link(__MODULE__, nil, [name: __MODULE__])
    GenServer.call(__MODULE__, :reset)
  end

  @spec add(left :: integer, right :: integer) :: any
  def add(left, right) do
    GenServer.call(__MODULE__, {:add, left, right})
  end

  @spec count() :: integer
  def count() do
    GenServer.call(__MODULE__, :count)
  end

  @impl true
  def init(_) do
    {:ok, nil}
  end

  @impl true
  def handle_call(:reset, _, _) do
    {:reply, true, {:gb_trees.empty, 0}}
  end

  def handle_call({:add, left, right}, _, {tree, count}) do
    iter = :gb_trees.iterator_from(left - 1, tree)
    {tree, count} = update_tree({tree, count}, left, right, iter)
    {:reply, true, {tree, count}}
  end

  def handle_call(:count, _, {tree, count}) do
    {:reply, count, {tree, count}}
  end

  defp update_tree({tree, count}, left, right, iter) do
    case :gb_trees.next(iter) do
      {hi, lo, iter} when lo <= right + 1 ->
        tree = :gb_trees.delete(hi, tree)
        count = count - hi + lo - 1
        left = min(left, lo)
        right = max(right, hi)
        update_tree({tree, count}, left, right, iter)
      _ ->
        tree = :gb_trees.insert(right, left, tree)
        count = count + right - left + 1
        {tree, count}
    end
  end
end

# Your functions will be called as such:
# CountIntervals.init_()
# CountIntervals.add(left, right)
# param_2 = CountIntervals.count()

# CountIntervals.init_ will be called before every test case, in which you can do some necessary initializations.
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
At the end of the day, the count is just the length of each interval summed together, inclusive.

We would need to:

1. Efficiently detect when an intersection exists
2. Keep a dynamic counter of the current count and update it each time we try to add an interval to our class. 

# Approach
For efficiently detecting intersections, we can simply store the intervals using a BST (i.e. a TreeMap if you know Java). The key is the end of the interval, and the value is the start of the interval.

To detect an intersection with a new interval, we first check to see the smallest key that is higher than the  new interval's start. 

If there is not one, then there is no intersection, and we can simply add right - left + 1 to our dynamic counter.

Otherwise, we check to see that the start of the interval corresponding to the that higher key is less than or equal to the end of the new interval's end. 

If this is the case, we have an intersection. We remove the higher interval, subtract off its length, and then try to recusively add the interval that would appear if we merged the new interval and this higher interval. This new interval would be (min of the starts, max of the ends). 

Otherwise, there is no intersection and we can add right - left + 1 to our dynamic counter.

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

count is O(1)
Worst case for a single add is O(NLogN), where N is the number of intervals added so far.

- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
O(N), where N is the number of intervals added so far.

# Code
```
from typing import Optional

from sortedcontainers import SortedList

class CountIntervals:
    class TreeMap:

        def __init__(self):
            self.keys = SortedList()
            self.map = {}

        # get the smallest key greater than or equal to i
        def higher(self, i: int) -> Optional[int]:
            index  = self.keys.bisect_left(i)

            if index < len(self.keys):
                return self.keys[index]

            return None

        def put(self, key: int, val: int) -> None:
            if key not in self.map:
                self.keys.add(key)

            self.map[key] = val

        def get(self, key: int) -> int:
            assert key in self.map
            return self.map[key]

        def remove(self, key):
            assert key in self.map
            del self.map[key]
            self.keys.remove(key)


    def __init__(self):
        self.treemap = CountIntervals.TreeMap()
        self.amt = 0

    def add(self, left: int, right: int) -> None:
        # find intersection

        currAmount = right - left + 1
        higherEnd = self.treemap.higher(left)

        # base case, no possible intersection detected
        if higherEnd is None:
            self.treemap.put(right, left)
            self.amt += currAmount

        # possible intersection
        else:
            higherStart = self.treemap.get(higherEnd)

            # intersection detected
            if higherStart <= right:
                oldAmount = higherEnd - higherStart + 1

                self.treemap.remove(higherEnd)
                self.amt -= oldAmount

                # beast, just drop the old interval, subtract off its length, and recursively try to add the new combined interval in case it intersects with multiple future intervals
                self.add(min(left, higherStart), max(right, higherEnd))


            # base case 2, false positive in terms of an intersection
            else:
                self.treemap.put(right, left)
                self.amt += currAmount

    def count(self) -> int:
        return self.amt

# Your CountIntervals object will be instantiated and called as such:
# obj = CountIntervals()
# obj.add(left,right)
# param_2 = obj.count()
```

```
from sortedcontainers import SortedList

class CountIntervals:

    def __init__(self):
        self.intervals, self.countOfInts = SortedList(), 0

    def add(self, left: int, right: int) -> None:
        # Find the position of insertion
        posOfInsertion = bisect_right(self.intervals, left, key = lambda x: x[0])
        # If previous index could be merged, check that too.
        if posOfInsertion > 0 and self.intervals[posOfInsertion - 1][1] >= left:
            posOfInsertion -= 1
        # leftPos is the starting index for popping items from BST
        # leftVal and rightVal are the lower and upper bounds of the new interval
        leftVal, rightVal, leftPos = left, right, posOfInsertion
        while posOfInsertion < len(self.intervals) and self.intervals[posOfInsertion][0] <= right:
            self.countOfInts -= (self.intervals[posOfInsertion][1]- self.intervals[posOfInsertion][0] + 1)
            leftVal = min(self.intervals[posOfInsertion][0], leftVal)
            rightVal = max(self.intervals[posOfInsertion][1], rightVal)
            posOfInsertion += 1
        # Pop the items from BST since they will be merged.
        while leftPos < posOfInsertion:
            self.intervals.pop(index = leftPos)
            posOfInsertion -= 1
        # Add the new interval
        self.intervals.add([leftVal, rightVal])
        # update the count
        self.countOfInts += (rightVal - leftVal + 1)

    def count(self) -> int:
        return self.countOfInts

```

```
class CountIntervals:

    def __init__(self):
        self.intervals, self.countOfInts = SortedList(), 0

    def add(self, left: int, right: int) -> None:
        # Find the position of insertion
        posOfInsertion = bisect_right(self.intervals, left, key = lambda x: x[0])
        # If previous index could be merged, check that too.
        if posOfInsertion > 0 and self.intervals[posOfInsertion - 1][1] >= left:
            posOfInsertion -= 1
        # leftPos is the starting index for popping items from BST
        # leftVal and rightVal are the lower and upper bounds of the new interval
        leftVal, rightVal, leftPos = left, right, posOfInsertion
        while posOfInsertion < len(self.intervals) and self.intervals[posOfInsertion][0] <= right:
            self.countOfInts -= (self.intervals[posOfInsertion][1]- self.intervals[posOfInsertion][0] + 1)
            leftVal = min(self.intervals[posOfInsertion][0], leftVal)
            rightVal = max(self.intervals[posOfInsertion][1], rightVal)
            posOfInsertion += 1
        # Pop the items from BST since they will be merged.
        while leftPos < posOfInsertion:
            self.intervals.pop(index = leftPos)
            posOfInsertion -= 1
        # Add the new interval
        self.intervals.add([leftVal, rightVal])
        # update the count
        self.countOfInts += (rightVal - leftVal + 1)

    def count(self) -> int:
```

solutions.content:
The idea is to maintain the intervals in the collection non-overlapped. 
To add a new interval (left, right), we try to merge it with existing overlapped intervals by considering following cases:

1. (left, right) is fully covered by an existing interval, then we have nothing to do. 
2. (left, right) overlaps with its left interval, then we merge the two.
3. (left, right) overlaps with its right interval, then we also merge the two. 
4. (left, right) fully covers some existing intervals, then we discard all the covered, smaller intervals. 

During each merge, the total covered number will be updated at the same time. 
To faciliate the computation, the collection of intervals is implemented with an ordered list such as SortedList in python3. 

```
from sortedcontainers import SortedList

class CountIntervals:
    def __init__(self):
        self.total = 0
        self.tree = SortedList()
        
    def add(self, left: int, right: int) -> None:
        overlaps = [(l, r) for l, r in self.tree.irange((left, -inf), (right, inf)) if r >= left]
        prev = self.tree.bisect_left((left, -inf)) - 1
        if prev >= 0:
            l, r = self.tree[prev]
			# Do nothing if the current interval is fully covered by an existing interval
            if r >= right:
                return 
			# Merge the current interval with its left one if they are overlapped
            if r >= left:
                left = l
                self.total -= (r - l + 1)
                self.tree.remove((l, r))
        if overlaps:
            l, r = overlaps[-1]
			# Merge the current interval with its right one if they are overlapped
            if l <= right and r >= right:
                right = r
                self.total -= (r - l + 1)
                self.tree.remove((l, r))
                overlaps.pop()
			# Discard all the smaller intervals that are covered by the current interval
            for l, r in overlaps:
                self.total -= r - l + 1   
                self.tree.remove((l, r)) 
		# Finally, adding the merged, non-overlapped interval into the collection
        self.total += (right - left + 1)
        self.tree.add((left, right))    
            
    def count(self) -> int:
        return self.total

```
from sortedcontainers import SortedList
class CountIntervals:

    def __init__(self):
```
        self.container = SortedList([])
        self.numbers = 0

    def add(self, left: int, right: int) -> None:
        if len(self.container) == 0:
            self.container.add([left,right])
            self.numbers += (right-left+1)
            return
        #get first smallest to the right
        idx = self.find_idx(right)
        if idx == -1 or idx == len(self.container):
            self.container.add([left,right])
            self.numbers += (right-left+1)
            return
        ele = self.container[idx]
        if ele[1] >= left:
            l = left
            r = right
            #remove all overlapping intervals
            while idx >= 0 and l <= self.container[idx][1]:
                ele = self.container[idx]
                self.container.pop(idx)
                self.numbers -= (ele[1]-ele[0]+1)
                l,r = min(ele[0],l),max(ele[1],r)
                idx -= 1
            self.container.add([l,r])
            self.numbers += (r-l+1)
        else:
            self.container.add([left,right])
            self.numbers += (right-left+1)
        return
    def find_idx(self,num):
        low = 0
        high = len(self.container) - 1
        ans = len(self.container)
        while low <= high:
            mid = (low+high)//2
            if self.container[mid][0] <= num:
                ans = mid
                low = mid+1
            else:
                high = mid-1
        if ans == 0:
            if self.container[0][0] > num:
                return -1
        return ans
    def count(self) -> int:
        return self.numbers
 ```

```
from sortedcontainers import SortedList

class CountIntervals:

    def __init__(self):
        self.cov = 0 
        self.interv = SortedList([(-inf, -inf), (inf, inf)])

    def add(self, left: int, right: int) -> None:
        li = self.interv.bisect_left((left - 1, -inf))
        if self.interv[li - 1][1] >= left - 1:
            li -= 1
        lval = min(self.interv[li][0], left)
        ri = self.interv.bisect_right((right + 1, inf))
        rval = max(self.interv[ri - 1][1], right)
        
        
        to_delete = 0
        for _ in range(li, ri):
            to_delete += self.interv[_][1] - self.interv[_][0] + 1
        self.cov += rval - lval + 1 - to_delete
        del self.interv[li: ri]
        self.interv.add((lval, rval))

    def count(self) -> int:
        return self.cov
```

from sortedcontainers import SortedList

class CountIntervals:

    def __init__(self):
        self.cov = 0 
        self.interv = SortedList([(-inf, -inf), (inf, inf)])

    def add(self, left: int, right: int) -> None:
        li = self.interv.bisect_left((left - 1, -inf))
        if self.interv[li - 1][1] >= left - 1:
            li -= 1
        lval = min(self.interv[li][0], left)
        ri = self.interv.bisect_right((right + 1, inf))
        rval = max(self.interv[ri - 1][1], right)
        
        
        to_delete = 0
        for _ in range(li, ri):
            to_delete += self.interv[_][1] - self.interv[_][0] + 1
        self.cov += rval - lval + 1 - to_delete
        del self.interv[li: ri]
        self.interv.add((lval, rval))

    def count(self) -> int:
        return self.cov

```scala

class CountIntervals() {

  val iMap = scala.collection.mutable.TreeMap.empty[Int, Int]

  var cnt = 0

  def add(left: Int, right: Int) {
    val leftInterval = iMap.maxBefore(left).filter(_._2 >= left)
    val rightIntervals = iMap.range(left, right + 1)
    val nLeft = leftInterval.map(_._1).getOrElse(left)
    val nRight = List(Some(right), leftInterval.map(_._2), rightIntervals.lastOption.map(_._2)).flatten.max
    (leftInterval ++ rightIntervals).foreach { case(l, r) =>
      iMap.remove(l)
      cnt -= distance(l, r)
    }
    iMap(nLeft) = nRight
    cnt += distance(nLeft, nRight)
  }

  def count(): Int = cnt

  def distance(left: Int, right: Int) = right - left + 1
}
```

solutions.content:
**Sorted List**

time: O(n*log(n))
space: O(n)
Runtime: 1184 ms, 83.14% 
Memory: 54.4 MB, 41.34%

```
from sortedcontainers import SortedList

class CountIntervals:
    def __init__(self):
        self.s = SortedList()    
        self.cnt = 0
        
    def delete(self, idx, left, right, x, y):
        self.s.pop(idx)
        left = min(left, x)
        right = max(right, y)
        self.cnt -= (y-x+1)
        return left, right
    
    def add(self, left: int, right: int) -> None:
        l = self.s.bisect_left((left,right))
        while l-1 >= 0:
            x, y = self.s[l-1]
            if y < left: break
            left, right = self.delete(l-1, left, right, x, y)
            l -= 1
        while l < len(self.s):
            x, y = self.s[l]
            if right < x: break
            left, right = self.delete(l, left, right, x, y)
        self.s.add((left, right))
        self.cnt += (right-left+1)

    def count(self) -> int:
        return self.cnt
```


**Segment Tree**

Inspired by user8856S' [comment](https://leetcode.com/problems/count-integers-in-intervals/discuss/2040221/Python-Segment-Tree-got-TLE.-Why).
time: O(n*log(n))
space: O(n)
Runtime: 6015 ms, 10.70%
Memory: 138.7 MB, 9.57%

```
class Node:
    def __init__(self):
        self.res = self.left = self.right = None
        
    def add(self, node, x, y, s, e):
        if e<=x or y<=s or node and node.res == y-x: return node
        if not node: node = Node()
        if s<=x and y<=e:
            node.res = y-x
            return node
        mid = (x+y)//2
        node.left = self.add(node.left, x, mid, s, e)
        node.right = self.add(node.right, mid, y, s, e)
        node.res = 0
        if node.left: node.res += node.left.res
        if node.right: node.res += node.right.res
        return node
        
class CountIntervals:
    def __init__(self):
        self.root = Node()

    def add(self, left: int, right: int) -> None:
        self.root.add(self.root, 1, 10**9+1, left, right+1)
        
    def count(self) -> int:
        return self.root.res or 0
```

```
from bisect import bisect_left, insort

class CountIntervals:

    def __init__(self):
        self.intervals = []
        self.cnt = 0

    def add(self, left: int, right: int) -> None:
        if not self.intervals or self.intervals[0][0] > right or self.intervals[-1][1] < left:
            insort(self.intervals, (left, right))
            self.cnt += right - left + 1
            return
        idx = bisect_left(self.intervals, (left, left))
        if idx > 0 and self.intervals[idx - 1][1] >= left: idx -= 1
        if self.intervals[idx][0] > right:
            insort(self.intervals, (left, right))
            self.cnt += right - left + 1
            return
        i, left, cur_right = idx, min(left, self.intervals[idx][0]), right
        while i < len(self.intervals) and self.intervals[i][0] <= right:
            cur_right = max(cur_right, self.intervals[i][1])
            self.cnt -= min(right, self.intervals[i][1]) - self.intervals[i][0] + 1
            i += 1
        self.cnt += right - left + 1
        self.intervals[idx:i] = [(left, cur_right)]

    def count(self) -> int:
        return self.cnt
```

```
        if self.intervals[idx][0] > right:
```

solutions.title: python3-single-built-in-list-968-ms-47-9-mb
solutions.content:
As reported by LeetCode (on 16 May 2022), this solution **beats `most of` other Python implementations in both runtime and memory efficiency** (~968 ms, ~47.9 MB). Although LeetCode reported `100%` instead of `most of`, I know that number is not very true.

Please, share your idea if you can optimise the implementation below further.

In this implementation, both the `left` and the `right` values of the added intervals are stored in a single sorted list. When adding a new interval to the the list, we can tell whether the new interval overlaps existing ones based on the indices returned from the `bisect_left` and `bisect_right` functions (see the code below).

```python
from bisect import bisect_left, bisect_right

class CountIntervals:

    def __init__(self):
        self._intervals = [0] * 20001  # pre-allocate the memory
        self._size = 0
        self._count = -1

    def add(self, left: int, right: int) -> None:
        if left > right:
            tmp = left
            left = right
            right = tmp

        if self._size == 0:
            self._size = 2
            self._intervals[:2] = [left, right]
        else:
            leftPos = bisect_left(self._intervals, left - 1, 0, self._size)
            rightPos = bisect_right(self._intervals, right + 1, leftPos, self._size)

            if leftPos % 2 == 1:
				# This means the new interval overlaps an existing one
                leftPos -= 1
                left = self._intervals[leftPos]
            elif leftPos < self._size and left > self._intervals[leftPos]:
                left = self._intervals[leftPos]

            if rightPos % 2 == 1:
				# This means the new interval overlaps an existing one
                right = self._intervals[rightPos]
                rightPos += 1
            elif rightPos > 0 and right < self._intervals[rightPos - 1]:
                right = self._intervals[rightPos - 1]

			# Modify the interval list in place (for memory efficiency)
            oldSize = self._size
            self._size = leftPos + 2 + (self._size - rightPos)			
            self._intervals[leftPos + 2 : self._size] = self._intervals[rightPos : oldSize]
            self._intervals[leftPos : leftPos + 2] = [left, right]

        self._count = -1  # invalidate self._count


    def count(self) -> int:
        if self._count < 0:
            self._count = 0
            for i in range(1, self._size, 2):
                self._count += self._intervals[i] - self._intervals[i-1] + 1
        return self._count
```

solutions.title: python-no-sortedcontainer-with-thought-process-being-asked-during-interviews
solutions.content:
### Binary Search
We need to maintain the intervals for each `add` query and update the `count` for all of integers covered by intervals. We can use `TreeMap` in java or `ordered map` in C++ to implement `interval search tree`, which sorts the `left` as the key with `right` as value. 
However, in python, we don't have built-in library for sorted contianers. You might quickly figure it out using `SortedContainer` library, but I wasn't familar with it, and used the standard list to implemente it.If you want to know how to do it, keep reading.

The idea using standard list is that we put the pair of `left` and `right` in the order, so each interger at even index is `left` and the one at odd index is `right`. We can tell whether the current integer is `left` or `right` by checking the index. So the length of the list is always even. 
For each `add`, we find the index for `left` and `right` to fall in the list using binary search. And sum up all of intervals covered by the `index of (left, right)` to update the count of integers being covered.
The difficulty part is to deal with merging for different edge cases since there are 4 cases for combinations of index of `left` and `right`.
1. `left`: even, `right`: even.
   We have larger interval to insert, covering completely a couple of intervals. For example, `[2,5,8,10]` to insert `[1, 11]` or `[1, 6]`, or `[6, 7]`. So we just override the `[i:j]` with the new `(left, right)`.
	 Since intervals are covered completely, we can simply sum up of length of intervals covered.
	 ```
	 tree[i: j] = [left, right]
	 sum = query(tree[i: j])
	 ```
	 
2. `left`: odd, `right`: even.
   We have the `right` overlapping with other intevals, not for `left`.  For example, `[2,5,8,10]` to insert `[1, 9]` or `[1, 3]`, or `[6, 9]`. So we just override the `[i:j]` with the new `(left)` only since `left` is merged to intervals.
	 Since intervals are covered partially, we have to sum up of length of intervals covered plus `right` because `right` overlapps with the last one of covered intervals.
	 ```
	 tree[i: j] = [left]
	 sum = query(tree[i: j] + [right])
	 ```
	
3. `left`: even, `right`: odd.
   Similarly with 2, we have the `left` overlapping with other intevals, not for `right`.  For example, `[2,5,8,10]` to insert `[3, 11]` or `[3, 6]`, or `[9, 11]`. So we just override the `[i:j]` with the new `(right)` only since `right` is merged to intervals.
	 Since intervals are covered partially, we have to sum up of length of intervals covered plus `left` because `left` overlapps with the last one of covered intervals.
	 ```
	 tree[i: j] = [right]
	 sum = query([left] + tree[i: j])
	 ```
	
4. `left`: even, `right`: even.
      We have both of `left` and `right` overlapping with other intevals. For example, `[2,5,8,10]` to insert `[3, 4]` or `[3, 9]`. So we just override the `[i:j]` with the new `()`  since mergeing all of intervals covered.
	 Since intervals are covered partially, we have to sum up of length of intervals covered plus  `left` and `right`.
	 ```
	 tree[i: j] = []
	 sum = query([left] + tree[i: j] + [right])
	 ```
	 
```python
class CountIntervals:

	def __init__(self):
		self.st = []
        self.c = 0
        
    def add(self, left: int, right: int) -> None:
        i = bisect.bisect_left(self.st, left)
        j = bisect.bisect(self.st, right)
		self.c += right - left + 1
        if not i % 2 and not j % 2: # even even
            self.c -= self.query(self.st[i: j])
            self.st[i:j] = [left, right]
        elif i % 2 and not j % 2:
            self.c -= self.query([left] + self.st[i: j])
            self.st[i: j] = [right]
        elif not i % 2 and j % 2:     
            self.c -= self.query(self.st[i: j] + [right])
            self.st[i: j] = [left]
        else:      
            self.c -= self.query([left] + self.st[i:j] + [right])
            self.st[i:j] = []

    def query(self, nums):       
        return sum(nums[i + 1] - nums[i] + 1 for i in range(0, len(nums), 2))
        
    def count(self) -> int:
        return self.c
        
```


*Time Complexity*= **O(lgN + N)** for each `add` call, since `insert` in standard list is linear.
*Space Complexity* = **O(N)**

```python
class CountIntervals:

	def __init__(self):
		self.st = []
        self.c = 0
        
    def add(self, left: int, right: int) -> None:
        i = bisect.bisect_left(self.st, left)
        j = bisect.bisect(self.st, right)
		self.c += right - left + 1
        if not i % 2 and not j % 2: # even even
            self.c -= self.query(self.st[i: j])
            self.st[i:j] = [left, right]
        elif i % 2 and not j % 2:
            self.c -= self.query([left] + self.st[i: j])
            self.st[i: j] = [right]
        elif not i % 2 and j % 2:     
            self.c -= self.query(self.st[i: j] + [right])
            self.st[i: j] = [left]
        else:      
            self.c -= self.query([left] + self.st[i:j] + [right])
            self.st[i:j] = []

    def query(self, nums):       
        return sum(nums[i + 1] - nums[i] + 1 for i in range(0, len(nums), 2))
        
    def count(self) -> int:
        return self.c
```

```
from sortedcontainers import SortedList


class CountIntervals:

    def __init__(self):
        self.q = SortedList()
        self.cnt = 0
        

    def add(self, left: int, right: int) -> None:
        if not self.q: 
            self.q.add([left, right])
            self.cnt += right - left + 1
            return
        loc = bisect.bisect(self.q, [left, right])
        
        # calibrate left and right bound in case of nested intervals: add [2, 2] to [1, 3]
        # though left will be expanded to 1 but right will still be 2 if not calibrated
        left = min(left, self.q[loc][0]) if loc < len(self.q) else left
        right = max(right, self.q[loc-1][1]) if loc > 0 else right
        
        # expand right bound
        tmp = loc
        while tmp < len(self.q) and right >= self.q[tmp][0]:
            s, e= self.q.pop(tmp)
            self.cnt -= e - s + 1
            if right <= e:
                right = e

        # expand left bound
        tmp = loc - 1
        while tmp >= 0 and left <= self.q[tmp][1]:
            s, e= self.q.pop(tmp)
            self.cnt -= e - s + 1
            if left >= s:
                left = s
            tmp -= 1
        self.q.add([left, right])
        self.cnt += right - left + 1

    def count(self) -> int:
        return self.cnt
```
